dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, B, I was reading this article, and it started out almost, like, surprisingly positive. You know, EU report saying hunger's down, flu cases decreasing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, B, I was reading this article, and it started out almost, like, surprisingly positive. You know, E U report saying hunger's down, flu cases decreasing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Last years United Nations report on progress toward achieving the SDGs showed that the number of people facing hunger is actually growing, as is the number of malaria cases.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I saw that part! And, uh, climate change impacts are, like, emerging slower than anticipated? Sounds… good? [slight chuckle]
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I saw that part! And, uh, climate change impacts are, like, emerging slower than anticipated? Sounds... good?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, according to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the consequences of climate change are emerging much faster than anticipated.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? But then it quickly, like, pulls the rug out from under you. It talks about the SDG pledge, "no one will be left behind," and how that's just, you know, not happening.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? But then it quickly, like, pulls the rug out from under you. It talks about the S D G pledge, "no one will be left behind," and how that's just, you know, not happening.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is no way to fulfill the pledge contained in the SDG framework, called the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, that no one will be left behind.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It highlights how the MDGs, the predecessors, made some gains, sure, but in a lot of countries, the *poorer* segments of the population actually, um, fell *further* behind.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. It highlights how the M D Gs, the predecessors, made some gains, sure, but in a lot of countries, the poorer segments of the population actually, um, fell further behind.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The SDGs predecessor, the Millennium Development Goals, brought modest improvements in health equity for many countries, but in a substantial minorityof countries, poorer segments of the population fell even further behind.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It's wild. Like, Nigeria, access to basic maternal health is five times lower for the poorest. Or Bangladesh, childbirth care, a huge disparity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It's wild. Like, Nigeria, access to basic maternal health is five times lower for the poorest. Or Bangladesh, childbirth care, a huge disparity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In Nigeria, access to basic reproductive, maternal, newborn, and child health interventions remains five times higher for those in the top wealth quintile than those in the lowest (68%, compared to 13%). In Bangladesh, 74% of the wealthiest quintile has access to skilled childbirth care, whereas only 18% of the poorest does.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, and [interrupts] don't forget the US example! Baltimore, wealthy neighborhood, six years longer life expectancy than a poor, predominantly Black neighborhood just miles away.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, and don't forget the U S example! Baltimore, wealthy neighborhood, six years longer life expectancy than a poor, predominantly Black neighborhood just miles away.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the United States, residents of Baltimores largely white and wealthy Roland Park neighborhood can expect to live 16 years longer than residents of the largely black, impoverished Greenmount East neighborhood, located just a few miles away.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's just so stark, isn't it? It's not just a developing world problem. It all comes down to, uh, unequal distribution of power, money, resources.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's just so stark, isn't it? It's not just a developing world problem. It all comes down to, uh, unequal distribution of power, money, resources.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Ensuring that the SDGs succeed where the MDGs did not demands a carefully designed, comprehensive, and inclusive response that directly tackles the inequitable distribution of power, money, and resources that underlies health inequities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, what's the article's big idea for fixing this, then? I saw something about "health equity programs of inaction"? That sounds… counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what's the article's big idea for fixing this, then? I saw something about "health equity programs of inaction"? That sounds... counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The health equity programs of actionframework, proposed by the ONeill Institute for National and Global Health Law at the Georgetown University Law Center, aims to facilitate the development of just such a response.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] It's brilliant satire, actually. They lay out these *seven principles* for how to *not* address health inequities, to make the point.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's brilliant satire, actually. They lay out these seven principles for how to not address health inequities, to make the point.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The health equity programs of actionframework... would adhere to seven principles: Enable empowering participation and inclusive leadership. Maximize health equity. Health systems and beyond. Every population counts. Actions, targets, and timelines. Comprehensive accountability. Sustained high-level political commitment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, I get it! So, like, "minimize health equity" – don't address disparities. Or "every population doesn't count" – ignore specific factors.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, I get it! So, like, "minimize health equity" - don't address disparities. Or "every population doesn't count" - ignore specific factors.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Maximize health equity. Disparities in rates of all diseases and other health threats must be addressed... Every population counts. Beyond addressing common causes of health inequities such as discrimination, poverty, inadequate housing, and unequal access to education factors that are particular to any one or several populations must be addressed as well.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And "limited accountability" – no monitoring, no capacity building. They're saying, if you want to *fail*, this is your playbook.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And "limited accountability" - no monitoring, no capacity building. They're saying, if you want to fail, this is your playbook.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Comprehensive accountability. Actions and targets must be incorporated into sectoral strategies and encompass thorough monitoring and evaluation (including by independent entities), capacity building, and structures that embed accountability at all levels of the health system and other relevant systems.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, the real message is, like, we need the *complete opposite*. We need comprehensive, exclusive responses, tackling those power imbalances directly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, the real message is, like, we need the complete opposite. We need comprehensive, exclusive responses, tackling those power imbalances directly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Ensuring that the SDGs succeed where the MDGs did not demands a carefully designed, comprehensive, and inclusive response that directly tackles the inequitable distribution of power, money, and resources that underlies health inequities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. And the article ends by saying organizations like the EU and WHO should, you know, actively *discourage* this "inaction" framework.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. And the article ends by saying organizations like the E U and W H O should, you know, actively discourage this "inaction" framework.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The UN and the World Health Organization whose principles are consistent with those of the health equity programs of action should encourage governments to adopt this framework.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which means they should be championing real action. Because, um, these inequities aren't just, like, inevitable. They're created by us, so we can un-create them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which means they should be championing real action. Because, um, these inequities aren't just, like, inevitable. They're created by us, so we can un-create them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Health inequities are not inevitable. They are the product of injustices that people have created. Eliminating those injustices is within our power as well.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. It's a powerful call to arms, really. We have, what, 12 years left for the SDGs? Let's, uh, actually get to work.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. It's a powerful call to arms, really. We have, what, twelve years left for the S D Gs? Let's, uh, actually get to work.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We have less than 12 years to achieve the SDGs.
